prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell my girlfriend she can’t bring her friend to my apartment anymore?
A little over a month ago my girlfriend and her parents got into a fight so she came to stay with me until they made up.  I was really clear that this was just temporary until they patched things up.  

It was going fine until she started bringing one of her friends over.   I had met this girl a few times before.  I thought she was ok.  

My girlfriend is like a totally different person around her.   They both get nasty.  Really catty.  There have been a bunch of times that it’s bothered me.  

There was one time I came home and it suddenly got quiet as soon as I came in.  It was awkward so just to break the silence I said something like, “I’m beat” and they both busted out laughing hysterically.   I asked my girlfriend what was so funny and she just told me nothing.  It was kinda obvious that were laughing at my expense, whatever. 

Another time I was in my bedroom and came to the kitchen to make a sandwich.  They were in the living room.  I wasn’t paying attention to what they were saying.  I have no idea what it was about.  I thought it’d be nice to offer to make them some snacks so I started to offer and girlfriend’s friend cut me off and said, “shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it” in a really nasty way.  I thought to myself “well fuck you too”, but just said “actually nope” and took my sandwich back to my bedroom. 

The situation that sent me over the edge though happened yesterday.   It was my last day off and I wasn’t able to relax much on Monday.   I was in the living room playing a game and they came over.  Girlfriend asked if they could have the room and I go to the bedroom.   I said “nah I’m right in the middle of this, can you guys hang out in the bedroom?”   Friend gave the most sour ducking look and my girlfriend got an attitude.  “It’s just a stupid game, you can play it anytime”.  So I said, “ yeah I can play it anytime and I’m playing it now”.  Friend mumbled something I couldn’t hear and they went to the bedroom.  It’s a small apartment and I could hear them both bitch about me even with the tv on.  

My girlfriend is usually such a sweet and funny person, but when her friend is around it’s like a switch flips and she’s a totally different person.  I don’t get it.   I don’t really want to, I just don’t want to deal with it anymore.  I want to tell her not to bring her friend here anymore.  Also maybe start pushing her to try talking to her parents again.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the "WIBTA" post is in the wrong. Let's break down the situation.

The author is in a relationship and has been allowing his girlfriend to stay at his apartment after a conflict with her parents. He explicitly said it was temporary. Then, the girlfriend starts bringing her friend over. The author mentions that when this friend is around, his girlfriend becomes "nasty" and "catty." There are specific incidents where the friend and girlfriend have been dismissive or rude to him. The friend even made a sarcastic comment when he offered to make snacks. The last straw was when the girlfriend and friend complained about him while he was playing a game. The author now wants to tell his girlfriend not to bring her friend over anymore and encourage her to reconcile with her parents.

First, I need to assess the dynamics here. The key points are mutual respect and boundaries. The author had a temporary arrangement with his girlfriend, and it's clear he didn't expect her to bring her friend. The girlfriend's behavior changes significantly in her friend's presence, which the author finds uncomfortable and disrespectful. The friend's comments are clearly hostile, which adds to the tension.

The author is not asking to ban the friend outright but to stop bringing her to his apartment. Given that the friend's presence is causing conflict and the girlfriend is acting differently around her, the author has a right to set boundaries in his own home. The girlfriend's friend's behavior seems to contribute to the problem. The author isn't trying to control his girlfriend's social life entirely but is asking her to respect his space and the original agreement of the temporary stay.

On the other hand, maybe the girlfriend didn't realize how her friend's presence was affecting the author. It's possible she didn't intend to overstay or bring her friend without discussing it. However, the author had made the arrangement temporary, and introducing another person into the situation without considering his feelings might be an issue. But the main problem here is the friend's behavior and how it affects the relationship. The author is responding to actual incidents of disrespect and conflict, so setting a boundary by asking her not to bring the friend is reasonable.

Considering all that, the author is not in the wrong. The answer should be B.
